messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 58 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: FedScale: Benchmarking Model and System Performance of Federated Learning at Scale

Paper Abstract: Abstract We present FedScale, a federated learning (FL) benchmarking suite with realistic datasets and a scalable runtime to enable reproducible FL research. FedScale datasets encompass a wide range of critical FL tasks, ranging from image classification and object detection to language modeling and speech recognition. Each dataset comes with a unified evaluation protocol using real-world data splits and evaluation metrics. To reproduce realistic FL behavior, FedScale contains a scalable and extensible runtime. It provides high-level APIs to implement FL algorithms, deploy them at scale across diverse hardware and software backends, and evaluate them at scale, all with minimal developer efforts. We combine the two to perform systematic benchmarking experiments and highlight potential opportunities for heterogeneity-aware co-optimizations in FL. FedScale is open-source and actively maintained by contributors from different institutions at http://fedscale.ai. We welcome feedback and contributions from the community.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 58 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 58"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Common Voice Data",
        "Fox go dataset",
        "iNaturalist 2019",
        "MobiPerf",
        "Google Open Images Dataset",
        "PySyft",
        "Reddit Comment Data",
        "Stack Overflow Data",
        "Taobao Dataset",
        "Termux",
        "TensorFlow Federated",
        "Flower: A friendly federated learning framework",
        "Towards federated learning at scale: System design",
        "Leaf: A benchmark for federated settings",
        "FedEval: A benchmark system with a comprehensive evaluation model for federated learning",
        "EMNIST: an extension of MNIST to handwritten letters",
        "Semi-cyclic stochastic gradient descent",
        "Large scale interactive motion forecasting for autonomous driving : The waymo open motion dataset",
        "Personalized federated learning with theoretical guarantees: A model-agnostic meta-learning approach",
        "From lifestyle vlogs to everyday interactions",
        "Inverting gradients - how easy is it to break privacy in federated learning?",
        "Differentially private federated learning: A client level perspective",
        "An efficient framework for clustered federated learning",
        "FedML: A research library and benchmark for federated machine learning",
        "Amc: Automl for model compression and acceleration on mobile devices",
        "AI benchmark: All about deep learning on smartphones in 2019",
        "Practical and private (deep) learning without sampling or shuffling",
        "Advances and open problems in federated learning",
        "Error feedback fixes signsgd and other gradient compression schemes",
        "SCAFFOLD: Stochastic controlled averaging for federated learning",
        "Europarl: A Parallel Corpus for Statistical Machine Translation",
        "To relay or not to relay for inter-cloud transfers?",
        "Sol: A federated execution engine for fast distributed computation over slow networks",
        "Oort: Efficient federated learning via guided participant selection",
        "PyramidFL: Fine-grained data and system heterogeneity-aware client selection for efficient federated learning",
        "Federated optimization in heterogeneous networks",
        "Neural adaptive video streaming with Pensieve",
        "Mlperf training benchmark",
        "Image-based recommendations on styles and substitutes",
        "Communication-efficient learning of deep networks from decentralized data",
        "Adaptive federated optimization",
        "Coqa: A conversational question answering challenge",
        "FedJAX: Federated learning simulation with jax",
        "Fetchsgd: Communication-efficient federated learning with sketching",
        "Mobilenetv2: Inverted residuals and linear bottlenecks",
        "Effects of age and gender on blogging",
        "Fed-ensemble: Improving generalization through model ensembling in federated learning",
        "Hollywood in homes: Crowdsourcing data collection for activity understanding",
        "Swan: A neural engine for efficient dnn training on smartphone socs",
        "Can you really backdoor federated learning?",
        "Attack of the tails: Yes, you really can backdoor federated learning",
        "Speech commands: A dataset for limited-vocabulary speech recognition",
        "Google landmarks dataset v2 a large-scale benchmark for instance-level recognition and retrieval",
        "Learning in situ: a randomized experiment in video streaming",
        "Characterizing impacts of heterogeneity in federated learning upon large-scale smartphone data",
        "Applied federated learning: Improving Google keyboard query suggestions",
        "Fine-grained gpu sharing primitives for deep learning applications",
        "Libritts: A corpus derived from librispeech for text-to-speech"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 58 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in FedScale: Benchmarking Model and System Performance of Federated Learning at Scale, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
